patterns.image_prompt: A transversal view of a ship being built, showing the bulkheads
patterns.short_description: My system isolate functionalities to reduce the blast radius when problems occur

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we encourage architects to use middleware to enable asynchronous data exchanges between systems, to avoid tight coupling and to enable the decoupling of systems. The implementation of Event driven architecture is a good example of this pattern, and Kafka is a recommended tool.
patterns.short_description: My systems use middleware to enable asynchronous data exchanges
My systems collaborate with third parties to make sure they can handle my workload

patterns.icon_prompt: Generate a graphic icon with simple design and a single green color on a white background and a line art style. The image consists of a circle with an open end on the right side where an arrow points clockwise. Inside the circle, there are three vertical lines that have the same height. This kind of icon might be used to represent concepts like cycle, refresh, update, or continuous processes.
patterns.short_description: My systems operate indefinitely in well known and monitored conditions
Business has defined expectations of my system's availability and performance
My systems' architecture is continuously re-evaluated and adapted taking in account production feedback
My data exchanges ensure consistency & integrity between systems
My systems expose robust and resilient APIs
I create digital applications improving the customer experience while preserving the planet

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we encourage architects to regularly review their application portfolio to identify and execute modernization and decommissioning opportunities proactively.
patterns.short_description: I analyze my application portfolio to identify and execute modernization opportunities on a regular basis
My systems are designed as a sum of independent services to ensure scalability, operability and agility
My systems are designed to gracefully handle internal errors
My systems are protected from third party failures

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we encourage build teams to leverage ephemereal environments to avoid having to provision Virtual machines based test environments that are costly, resource consuming (not friendly with the environment) and lack agility.
patterns.short_description: I create temporary and disposable development and testing environments
My systems log information necessary for troubleshooting and monitoring
Committed changes automatically trigger the build of the entire application as well as the automated tests

patterns.image_prompt: A monkey randomly pulling out cables in a data center
patterns.short_description: I voluntarily inject chaos in my system to understand its behavior and learn how to recover and improve
My systems' logs use standard error severities agreed between the build and operations
My systems are observable: Health Checks, Technical Golden Signals and End User Experience (SLI)
Tests are conducted at production scale on identical infrastructure. They encompass real-world user journeys.
My systems' dataflows are easy to monitor and diagnose thanks to correlation (UUIDs...)
Before starting a task, my systems ensure it has a chance to be fully completed
My systems are configured to stop before being fully overloaded

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we encourage build teams to regularly update their application dependencies and runtimes and to not wait for obsolescence of their dependencies. We encourage in this pattern that they regularly review their main dependencies and integrate modernization efforts in their product roadmaps directly.
patterns.short_description: Upgrading my system's components and dependencies with latest supported version is a recurrent planned activity

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we encourage build teams to assess the environmental impact and resource consumption of all technical components of their development and runtime stack, and also encourage them to have both architecture and development practices that are sustainable from an energy consumption standpoint.
patterns.short_description: I implement sustainable architecture and development practices

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we encourage teams to continuously, periodically reassess and reevaluate the energy consumption of their IT systems, during their complete lifecycle, from the initial design all the way till the final decommissioning of their system.
patterns.short_description: I integrate environmentally conscious principles into all aspects of a system's lifecycle
I anticipate and forecast systems activities and needs, to guarantee service level objectives and system capacity
During critical failures, teams have the power to activate all relevant experts to restore production

patterns.image_prompt: A detective looking for clues at a crime scene in a data center
patterns.short_description: During a failure my systems retain relevant logs and data to enable both quick resolution and cold analysis
Sharing and capitalizing knowledge continuously across teams is a corner stone of efficient operations

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we encourage teams to embrace failures and see them as opportunities to improve and learn something that they didn't know. We encourage them to do post-mortems and root cause analysis.
patterns.short_description: I see failures as opportunities to continuously learn and improve
I proactively set up my golden signals and SLIs in order to reduce time to detect situations

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we encourage teams to implement the Event management ITIL practice that monitors all events of the IT infrastructure, in order to react as quickly as possible when situations occur.
patterns.short_description: My systems send notifications as soon as possible to deal with situations
My systems react automatically to an event or make users autonomous to minimize request to operations
I know my users to provide a consistent and responsive user experience with appropriate channels for their work
My systems provide data that enable the understanding of usage
Tracking any type of asset that have a relationship with my systems is the foundation of efficient operations
I start my environment only when I use it, it remains off by default
Service Level Objective violations must be anticipated & trigger consequences
I deploy my systems with an automation tool which guarantees deployment is fast and reproducible
I make sure that all required contributors are prepared and involved during a change on my systems to ensure prompt reaction
My systems can be deployed in small increments and enable easy upgrade or roll-back
Each change is a complete re-provisioning of the environment, ensuring its configuration is 100% defined as code

patterns.prompt: With this pattern, we recommend that teams use an automated test to quickly validate the success of their changes
patterns.short_description: I have automated tests which validate the most critical functionalities, enabling quick and early post change validation

anti_patterns.image_prompt: A domino chain reaction with 10 dominoes
anti_patterns.short_description: Failures of a system propagate to all its highly coupled third parties
Go live of my systems is not gradual and is a one shot and very risky operation
Changing systems in production is risky so I avoid it at all cost

anti_patterns.image_prompt: A super hero saving the day
anti_patterns.short_description: Only a few specific members of my team know how to solve the issues my systems face
My systems only implement the happy paths with no design for failure
When a system connects with another system, it takes on board failures and problems of the latter

anti_patterns.image_prompt: A person with an hammer in hand, trying to smash a fly
anti_patterns.short_description: I use drastic measures that have a large impact to fix simple issues
My systems are reporting too many errors which are either not relevant or not associated with an actual problem

anti_patterns.image_prompt: A firefighter trying to stop a fire that is burning a computer
anti_patterns.short_description: My operations are driven by incoming incidents and are not proactive
The lowest system's availability is the one of all its coupled dependencies

anti_patterns.image_prompt: A person quickly running towards without seeing that there is a hazard in front of them
anti_patterns.short_description: Restoring a system during an outage is the top priority but not taking enough time for collecting data or analyzing

anti_patterns.image_prompt: A snow ball becoming bigger and bigger as it goes down a hill
anti_patterns.short_description: Simple problems in my systems grow bigger over time and generate unmanageable situations

anti_patterns.image_prompt: A person finger pointing at another
anti_patterns.icon_prompt: a finger pointing to the right
anti_patterns.short_description: When an incident occurs, the first reflex is to find the responsible person

anti_patterns.image_prompt: An image of someone with a large ball and chain attached to its leg, trying to work on his computer
anti_patterns.short_description: Maintaining my systems in production requires painful and recurring manual tasks and checks

anti_patterns.image_prompt: An old server in a datacenter, under a snowfall
anti_patterns.short_description: My systems are the result of accumulating numerous changes over time and are not reproductible

anti_patterns.image_prompt: An highway with a lot of lanes, with cars and trucks all converging to a single toll booth operated by a human, creating a massive traffic jam, after the tool booth, only a single lane remains
anti_patterns.short_description: The resources consumed by my system are maladjusted to the tasks to be performed
Some operations done on my production systems are not tracked or auditable
I don't have a complete and detailed view of the components which my systems rely on

anti_patterns.image_prompt: A cat walking on a keyboard, typing random text in a business web application
anti_patterns.short_description: You never know how users will use a system
I use IT/Digital diregarding the finite nature of our environment and its overexploitation
Delaying to a later time leads to negative consequences and increased stress in the long run
